awd_titl_txt: CAA:   Molecular Basis for the Cholinergic Modulation of Auditory Hair Cell Properties
awd_abstract_narration: In the mammalian inner ear a subpopulation of the sensory cells receive inhibitory inputs from the brain.  Neuronal feedback pathways such as this one, from the brain to the sensory organ are called efferent or descending pathways.  Similar neural feedback modulates sensory perception also in the lateral lines of fish and in the inner ears of reptiles, amphibians, and birds.  The fact that this efferent inhibition has been conserved across animal classes suggests the fundamental importance of this process.  This auditory efferent pathway contributes to the exquisite sensitivity and frequency selectivity of our sense of hearing by modulating the excitability of the sensory cells.  However, the mechanisms underlying this modulatory feedback are not understood at the molecular level.  It is known that the acetylcholine receptors alpha 9 and alpha 10 and the small conductance Ca2+-activated potassium channels SK2, which are often co-localized with calcium sources are required molecular components in the mammalian auditory sensory cells.  This project applies a molecular biology strategy to identify proteins involved in the selective localization, clustering, and functional associations between these ion channels.  Additionally, fluorescently tagged chimeras of the SK2 and of the alpha 9/ alpha 10 receptors have been constructed to apply state-of-the-art optical techniques to the investigation of the biochemical basis of their functional interactions.  The findings will advance our understanding of the biochemical principles underlying sensory perception including protein-protein interactions between the ion channels involved.  While completing this project graduate students and post-doctoral fellows will be trained to utilize powerful electrophysiological and optical research techniques as well as biochemical and molecular techniques.  These are essential techniques in neuroscience and other biological research frontiers for which a detailed understanding of macromolecular complexes harboring ion channels in excitable cells is fundamental.

por.por_cntn:
The central auditory system plays an important role in modulating cochlear function. This is accomplished by efferent innervation projecting to the auditory hair cells in the inner ear which exist in many diverse organisms. It is apparent that conservation of this system has been important to hearing. Yet, the molecular mechanisms at the hair cell level remain to be elucidated.  Various other neurotransmitters besides acetylcholine are also important however, it is well-established that a9 and a10 AChRs and SK2 channels are molecular constituents essential to the efferent effects on the cochlea.  Our goal was to understand how AChRs and SK2 channels are clustered at the postsynaptic terminals of auditory sensory hair cells. What other proteins are involved, and what are their specific roles as modulators of the functional interactions between the ion channels?  Also, are there other ion channels involved? In this context, it is notable that in most cases ion channels are components of dynamic macromolecular complexes.  However, the physiological roles of the protein partners have been studied in only a few examples.

In the auditory outer hair cells postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) are the source of Ca2+ influx which rapidly activates Ca2+-dependent small conductance potassium channels (SK2), resulting in hyperpolarization of these cells. We hypothesized that other proteins interact with AChRs and SK2 channels clustering them as macromolecular complexes that confer the fast efferent response of the OHCs.  The experiments performed during our funded period tested the direct interaction of the cytoplasmic domain of alpha 9 and alpha 10 AChR with MAGE-D2, GRSP-1, Anexin, candidate proteins to see if they had a role in the regulating the functional expression of the receptors and/or its association with scaffolding proteins.  Immunofluorescence experiments were performed which demonstrated the expression of some of the candidate proteins in the organ of Corti and specifically in the hair cells; for example.  MAGE-D2 was detected associated with efferent endings in the organ of Corti (see figure) 

Additionally, the project had significant impact on the career of the principal investigator, research associate and on the training of undergraduate students in the laboratory.  The activities during the duration of this project included building an electrophysiology set up and building expertise in methods essential for the study of ion channels.  Cell culture techniques, transfections, expression assays and other cell biology and electrophysiology techniques were incorporated to the training of students during the completion of this project.  The principal investigator served as mentor to undergraduate students including students in the Biology Undergraduate Scholar Program (BUSP).  The research increased awareness of hearing.  The research methods and results were presented in national meetings, and published in Journal of Cellular and Molecular Medicine and PLoS ONE.
